title: Triangle-Free Chromatic Threshold
description: Let h₃(k) be the smallest n with a triangle-free graph on n vertices of chromatic number k. Find the asymptotic formula. Known: (1/2 − o(1))k² log k ≤ h₃(k) ≤ (1 + o(1))k² log k. Is h₃(k+1)/h₃(k) → 1?

overview.historicalContext: Mycielski (1955) showed triangle-free graphs of arbitrarily high chromatic number exist. Graver and Yackel (1968) gave the first quantitative lower bound. The asymptotic behavior h₃(k) ~ Θ(k² log k) is known, but the constant factor remains open.
overview.problemStatement: Find an asymptotic formula for h₃(k). Is h₃(k+1)/h₃(k) → 1?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize triangle-free graphs, proper colorings, chromatic number, h₃(k), the main conjecture, known bounds, and small cases via Mycielski graphs.
keyInsights: Lower bound (1/2 − o(1))k² log k from probabilistic arguments
Upper bound (1 + o(1))k² log k from explicit constructions
The constant factor in the asymptotic is between 1/2 and 1
Mycielski's construction gives finite h₃(k) for all k

sections.title: Core Definitions
sections.summary: Defines triangle-free graphs, proper colorings, chromatic number, and h₃(k).

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Asymptotic formula h₃(k) ~ c·k²·log k and ratio convergence h₃(k+1)/h₃(k) → 1.

sections.title: Known Bounds
sections.summary: Lower bound (1/2 − o(1))k² log k, upper bound (1 + o(1))k² log k, and Graver–Yackel (1968).

sections.title: Structural Properties
sections.summary: Monotonicity, small cases h₃(1)=1, h₃(2)=2, h₃(3)=5, h₃(4)=11, and Mycielski's construction.

conclusion.summary: Formalizes Erdős Problem #1013 on the triangle-free chromatic threshold h₃(k). The constant in h₃(k) ~ c·k²·log k is known to lie in [1/2, 1] but its exact value remains open.
conclusion.implications: Determining the constant would resolve a fundamental question about the interplay between local structure (triangle-freeness) and global structure (chromatic number).
openQuestions: What is the exact asymptotic constant c in h₃(k) ~ c·k² log k?
What about the K_r-free generalization h_r(k)? (Problem #920)
